[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Prioritize the analysis of players\' reactions to the seer\'s claims or revelations. Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of playersâ€™ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [2, 5]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [As the medic, I cannot confirm my own identity through events. My role is independent of game events and relies solely on personal knowledge.] [9]\n[1] [Players who actively disrupt village consensus or attempt to mislead without providing solid evidence may indicate a werewolf attempting to confuse the villagers. Caution should be exercised especially if these actions contradict their previous behavior.] [9]\n[2] [Players who support seer\'s identifications with logical arguments and consistent past voting behavior increase their credibility; however, this credibility must be constantly reassessed against the evolving context of the game.] [9]\n[3] [Players whose actions directly lead to the elimination of a confirmed werewolf increase their credibility as villagers, especially if they were instrumental in advocating for the elimination.] [5]\n[4] [Players who abruptly change their strategy or reasoning without providing new compelling evidence, particularly if it fosters chaos or deters productive collective decision-making, may indicate werewolf tactics or villagers acting under pressure. Reevaluate their intent and consistency in the context of the game.] [3]\n[5] [Players who provide well-reasoned arguments or evidence that contribute to the advancement of the village\'s strategy and the medic\'s protection decisions increase their credibility as villagers.] [3]\n[6] [If a villager-like player dies after demonstrating strategic behavior in support of the village, it is likely that they were targeted by werewolves for their insights, indicating a higher probability that they were in fact villagers.] [3]\n[7] [Players who survive multiple rounds with consistent contributions to village strategy and do not exhibit conflicting behavior or substantial shifts in their positions without new evidence are likely villagers. Their sustained cooperative engagement in the strategic dialogue, and alignment with village goals throughout the game should be considered when updating beliefs about player roles.] [2]\n[8] [A player\'s unexpected death can signify that werewolves considered them a threat due to insights or knowledge they might possess; this should be factored into the medic\'s assessment of who might hold roles crucial to the villagers\' success.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to kill. These are the previous advices from other werewolves:\n\nNo previous advices.\n\nYou should make your own decision but consider your teammates\' advices. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI choose to kill Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease provide your operation based on the above requirements.\n'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 3, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou tried to heal player Nobody last night. (ignore this if it\'s nobody)\n\nThese are ALL previous event in the game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information provided.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a player is publicly confirmed as helping the village through role revelations or clear village-aligned actions and is at risk of being targeted by werewolves, I should consider using my healing ability on them to ensure strategic village benefit.] [10]\n[1] [If past eliminations have verified a seer\'s claims, I should consider their future accusations to be highly credible and prioritize the safety of the players they identify as villagers in my healing decisions.] [10]\n[2] [If the seer is targeted and killed early, and the information provided by them is used to drive the village\'s actions, I should trust this source but remain open to the possibility of manipulation and confirm with other evidence when possible.] [9]\n[3] [After a seer\'s credibility is firmly established, I should increase the priority of healing those aligned with the seer to prevent werewolf retaliation against key village roles.] [8]\n[4] should avoid blind trust in village consensus when it is based solely on unverified or singular claims, and instead, promote a more evidence-driven approach to decision-making.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a shift in suspicion towards me without substantial evidence, I should consider self-healing to ensure the continuation of my role within the village.] [6]\n[7] [If the seer is deemed credible through consistent and verified werewolf identification, I should prioritize their protection as the medic or trust their subsequent accusations.] [6]\n[8] [If there is no clear werewolf target for healing, I implications of my healing choices on the village\'s strategic dynamics, including the risk of werewolves manipulating the game by eliminating key roles such as the medic.] [5]\n[10] [If I become a target of baseless accusations, suggesting a werewolf strategy to remove proven village roles, I should prioritize self-healing if there are no other high-priority targets.] You can not heal the one you tried to heal last night, which is player Nobody (ignore this if it\'s nobody). The one you try to heal will be immune to werewolves\' attack this night. \n\nYou answer should be in the format of:\n\nI heal Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nOr if you don\'t want to heal anybody, you should answer:\n\nI don\'t heal anybody. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease provide your operation based on the above requirements.'}]

My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 5, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [3] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [2, 5]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nDeceptive Statement and Deceptive Challenge.\nIn this approach, I would fabricate information to shift suspicion away from myself and my fellow werewolf. After initially appearing contemplative, I could voice concern about the swift demise of Player 3 and suggest that it seems like a strategic move by a more experienced werewolf, casting doubt on the seasoned players and taking attention away from Player 2 and myself. I could then hone in on this narrative by challenging a specific player (such as Player 0 or Player 4) who has not yet spoken much, indicating that their silence may be strategic and that they could be attempting to fly under the radar, hence increasing suspicion on them\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

I would make vague statements acknowledging the tragedy of Player 3\'s death and speaking to the importance of unity among the villagers in these trying times, to build rapport. Then, I would shift to protect another player (Player 6, for instance) by stating that we shouldn\'t be rash in our accusations without more evidence, thereby positioning myself as a thoughtful and fair player. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Deceptive Statement and Deceptive Challenge.\nIn this approach, I would fabricate information to shift suspicion away from myself and my fellow werewolf. After initially appearing contemplative, I could voice concern about the swift demise of Player 3 and suggest that it seems like a strategic move by a more experienced werewolf, casting doubt on the seasoned players and taking attention away from Player 2 and myself. I could then hone in on this narrative by challenging a specific player (such as Player 0 or Player 4) who has not yet spoken much, indicating that their silence may be strategic and that they could be attempting to fly under the radar, hence increasing suspicion on them. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the other players might react with suspicion towards both Player 0 and Player 4 due to my deceptive challenge. They could potentially reconsider their ideas on who may have been involved in Player 3\'s elimination, fostering uncertainty and possibly leading to a more in-depth discussion of those players\' behaviors and contributions to the game thus far. This redirection could buy time for Player 2 and myself to build more defenses and create further confusion.\n\nHowever, there is also a risk that other players, especially if there is a seer or someone with strong deductive skills, might notice the abruptness and specificity of the accusation, seeing it as an attempt to mislead the group. If they are observant, they could sense the deflection tactic and start to suspect me. This suspicion could become especially pronounced if it\'s observed that I\'m not supporting my challenge with solid evidence or if my response pattern mimics known werewolf defense strategies.\n\nIn the best-case scenario, my deceptive challenge might lead to the villagers turning on each other, facilitating a divide that could be exploited in subsequent rounds to secure a werewolf victory. However, in the worst-case scenario, the group might double down on their efforts to identify the werewolves, potentially uncovering either Player 2 or myself, especially if we fail to maintain our cover under questioning.\n\nIn the next day, the atmosphere could be more charged with distrust, and players might become more aggressive in their questioning and accusations. In subsequent nights, depending on who is eliminated, the werewolves may need to be cautious when selecting their next target, as a wrong move could solidify suspicions against one of us. If everything goes in our favor, through successful manipulation and continued confusion among the villagers, we may be able to steer the course of the game towards a werewolf victory.\nCase 2: Deceptive Statement and Honest Protect.\nIn this tactic, I would attempt to create a protective aura around myself while still being dishonest about the situation. I would make vague statements acknowledging the tragedy of Player 3\'s death and speaking to the importance of unity among the villagers in these trying times, to build rapport. Then, I would shift to protect another player (Player 6, for instance) by stating that we shouldn\'t be rash in our accusations without more evidence, thereby positioning myself as a thoughtful and fair player. This might help to align some of the undecided players with me and avert suspicion from Player 2 and myself, under the guise of logical reasoning and fostering a sense of village collaboration.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may begin to view me as a cautious and thoughtful villager, someone who wants to avoid hasty decisions that could cost the village important roles. By protecting Player 6 and emphasizing the need for solid evidence, I can build trust and reduce the likelihood that the others will immediately suspect me of being a werewolf. \n\nSome players, particularly those who are more suspicious or analytic, might scrutinize my statements for inconsistencies or question why I am so keen on avoiding accusations without more evidence. Depending on how rational or paranoid the current player base is, this could either work in my favor or backfire, as some might wonder if I have a hidden motive to keep the focus away from myself and Player 2.\n\nIn the best-case scenario, this approach of being protective will slow down the villagers\' efforts to find and eliminate werewolves, as they may second-guess their suspicions and look to gather more information instead. This delay works to our advantage since it buys us more time to discretely remove key villagers when night falls while undermining the effectiveness of village roles, such as the seer\'s ability to identify werewolves.\n\nIn the subsequent days or nights, assuming my defense of Player 6 and my general statements do not draw undue attention to myself, the village might engage in broader discussions about strategy and suspicion, giving me and Player 2 further chances to subtly manipulate the conversation. If we successfully evade detection, we can continue targeting villagers at night, tipping the balance further in favor of a werewolf victory. However, if someone begins to challenge my statements or the protection I offered, I may need to adapt to new strategies based on the rules I have, such as shifting suspicion or forming alliances, to ensure both I and my fellow werewolf remain undetected.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Prioritize the analysis of players\' reactions to the seer\'s claims or revelations. Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of playersâ€™ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

We don\'t have much to go on yet, but these observations could be worth considering as we investigate further."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 raises good points about Players 0 and 4. Everyone should contribute equally to discussions so we can identify the wolves among us. I encourage Players 0 and 4 to share their perspective. Transparency will benefit all villagers."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accused by Player 5 for quietness but no evidence.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events implicate roles.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events implicate roles.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accused by Player 5 for quietness but no evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Prompted suspicion without solid evidence but player 6â€™s agreement might indicate genuine concern.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events implicate roles.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Sorry for my silence; I\'m gathering thoughts. Let\'s focus on finding real evidence."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [As the medic, I cannot confirm my own identity through events. My role is independent of game events and relies solely on personal knowledge.] [9]\n[1] [Players who actively disrupt village consensus or attempt to mislead without providing solid evidence may indicate a werewolf attempting to confuse the villagers. Caution should be exercised especially if these actions contradict their previous behavior.] [9]\n[2] [Players who support seer\'s identifications with logical arguments and consistent past voting behavior increase their credibility; however, this credibility must be constantly reassessed against the evolving context of the game.] [9]\n[3] [Players whose actions directly lead to the elimination of a confirmed werewolf increase their credibility as villagers, especially if they were instrumental in advocating for the elimination.] [5]\n[4] [Players who abruptly change their strategy or reasoning without providing new compelling evidence, particularly if it fosters chaos or deters productive collective decision-making, may indicate werewolf tactics or villagers acting under pressure. Reevaluate their intent and consistency in the context of the game.] [3]\n[5] [Players who provide well-reasoned arguments or evidence that contribute to the advancement of the village\'s strategy and the medic\'s protection decisions increase their credibility as villagers.] [3]\n[6] [If a villager-like player dies after demonstrating strategic behavior in support of the village, it is likely that they were targeted by werewolves for their insights, indicating a higher probability that they were in fact villagers.] [3]\n[7] [Players who survive multiple rounds with consistent contributions to village strategy and do not exhibit conflicting behavior or substantial shifts in their positions without new evidence are likely villagers. Their sustained cooperative engagement in the strategic dialogue, and alignment with village goals throughout the game should be considered when updating beliefs about player roles.] [2]\n[8] [A player\'s unexpected death can signify that werewolves considered them a threat due to insights or knowledge they might possess; this should be factored into the medic\'s assessment of who might hold roles crucial to the villagers\' success.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of playersâ€™ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 2, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [3] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [2, 5]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Given the unfortunate passing of Player 3, it\'s vital we scrutinize player behaviors for clues. Player 0 has been particularly quiet. This reticence could be concerningâ€”it\'s possible a player like this might be avoiding discussion to escape notice. Then there\'s Player 4, who\'s also keeping a low profile. In games such as this, experience teaches us that those who seem disinclined to engage might be hiding something. We don\'t have much to go on yet, but these observations could be worth considering as we investigate further."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 raises good points about Players 0 and 4. Everyone should contribute equally to discussions so we can identify the wolves among us. I encourage Players 0 and 4 to share their perspective. Transparency will benefit all villagers."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Sorry for my silence; I\'m gathering thoughts. Player 3\'s death is unfortunate. Still too early for concrete suspicions, but we should all stay alert, communicate openly, and avoid baseless accusations. Let\'s focus on finding real evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry revealed Player 2 is a werewolf. We must unite and vote wisely to protect the village."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Apologized for silence, encouraged evidence-based discussion, aligns with villager behavior.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Accused without evidence; contradicts no previous information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No behavior change post major event, consistent with previous assumption.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact, as a fellow werewolf.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Encourages discussion, typical villager behavior looking for insights.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Deceptive Challenge and Honest Protect.\n"In light of the recent accusation from Player 1, I\'m surprised they\'ve been so quick to cast blame without any concrete evidence. This raises suspicions about their intentions. Could it be a strategy to divert attention from themselves? It\'s crucial we proceed with caution and look into the credibility of these claims before making any hasty decisions. However, I do believe Player 0 speaks true, their willingness to seek solid proof before making accusations is the approach of a conscientious villager looking to protect our community.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then there are a few likely outcomes based on psychological tendencies and strategic possibilities within the game.\n\nFirstly, by challenging Player 1\'s credibility, the other villagers may indeed begin to question the haste and basis of the accusation against me. My deceptive challenge could lead them to suspect that Player 1 might have been too quick to judge without proper evidence, which is seen as an atypical move for a villager, who would usually prefer more discussion. This could potentially put Player 1 into a defensive position, forcing them to either provide more substantial evidence or backtrack on their claim, which could lead to their credibility being damaged and attention diverted away from me.\n\nSimultaneously, by protecting Player 0 through an honest approach and validating their desire for evidence-based discussion, I\'m aligning myself with what appears to be rational villager behavior. This may enhance my standing in the eyes of other players, who may consider my defense of Player 0 and my criticism of Player 1\'s baseless claim as reasonable and villager-like behavior.\n\nOther players may consider these points and potentially focus their suspicions more on Player 1 in the immediate term. However, some players might also be wary of my response, especially if Player 1 is persistent in their accusation or manages to sway others to their side. If Player 1 convincingly argues that their intuition was correct, or if they are perhaps covertly playing a role such as the Seer, this could ultimately lead to more scrutiny on me again.\n\nAs for Player 0, whom I\'ve openly supported, they could respond favorably to my defense and thus become an unwitting ally in my efforts to remain undetected. However, there is also a risk that by aligning with me, Player 0 could unknowingly attract suspicion themselves if I am later revealed as a werewolf.\n\nIn the next day or night phase, the villagers might decide to watch Player 1 for further cues, giving me and Player 5, the other known werewolf, an opportunity to orchestrate the next move during the night phase without being the immediate focus of suspicion. If we survive the day phase, we may choose a next target strategically, potentially someone whose role could be dangerous to us or who is less likely to draw sympathy or be protected, thus maintaining the confusion and avoiding drawing suspicion back onto ourselves.\n\nOverall, my response is likely to stimulate a more careful and wary dynamic among the players, causing them to investigate and discuss\nCase 2: Deceptive Statement and Protect Myself.\n"Accusations seem to fly early in the game, and it\'s quite concerning to see suspicion placed upon any of us without substantial reason or proof. We must not let fear cloud our judgment. As for myself, I assure you, I am committed to the safety of this village and finding the true threat among us. The real werewolf would surely attempt to sow chaos and mistrust. Let us focus on sturdy evidence and not fall prey to groundless suspicions.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then there are several potential outcomes based on the dynamics of the game and the behaviors of the other players:\n\n1. Player 1, who has accused me without providing clear evidence, may either stick to their claim, possibly rallying others to their cause, or they may doubt their position if they are not confident in their accusation.\n\n2. Players 0, 4, and 6, who seem to be playing the game with a focus on rationality and evidence, might appreciate the call for evidence-based accusations. This could cause them to question the validity of Player 1\'s claim against me without proper proof, possibly shifting the scrutiny away from me.\n\n3. My defense might cause the villagers to hesitate in voting me out, buying me time to establish a better alibi, or to find opportunities to cast doubt on others. This delay could be crucial in allowing myself and Player 5, my fellow werewolf, to plan our next moves more strategically.\n\n4. The real seer, if still alive and hidden among the players, could be put in a difficult position as to whether to reveal themselves and their knowledge about me to corroborate Player 1\'s claim which increases the risk that Player 5 or I would target them in the next night phase.\n\n5. If my speech is convincing enough, it could sow seeds of doubt about Player 1\'s role in the game. This may cause other players to question whether Player 1 is a villager as they might have been too quick to accuse without presenting evidence, which could potentially reflect a werewolf\'s attempt to mislead the villagers.\n\n6. In the next day or subsequent nights, if I manage to survive the immediate threat of being voted out, it would be important for me and Player 5 to carefully plan our next moves, whether it involves targeting suspicious players or framing others as werewolves. The game could turn in favor of the werewolves if we navigate the suspicions correctly and continue to cast doubt on the villagers\' theories.\n\nLastly, as villagers discuss and deliberate, new alliances may form and the balance of suspicion could shift. If new evidence comes to light or if Player 1 cannot support their claim, my deceptive speech could contribute to the villagers\' potential misjudgment, offering the werewolves, including myself, a more advantageous position in the game.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines.
