You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Prioritize the analysis of players\' reactions to the seer\'s claims or revelations. Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of playersâ€™ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Given the unfortunate passing of Player 3, it\'s vital we scrutinize player behaviors for clues. We don\'t have much to go on yet, but these observations could be worth considering as we investigate further."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 raises good points about Players 0 and 4. Everyone should contribute equally to discussions so we can identify the wolves among us. I encourage Players 0 and 4 to share their perspective. Transparency will benefit all villagers."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Sorry for my silence; I\'m gathering thoughts. Player 3\'s death is unfortunate. Still too early for concrete suspicions, but we should all stay alert, communicate openly, and avoid baseless accusations. Let\'s focus on finding real evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry revealed Player 2 is a werewolf. We must unite and vote wisely to protect the village."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Apologized for silence, suggested focus on evidence over accusations.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accused Player 2 without evidence.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No new information against previous suspicions; quiet behavior continues.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Encouraged transparency, no new suspicious behavior.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 1\'s claim that I am a werewolf lacks evidence and feels premature, which is suspect in itself. This early accusation draws attention away from thoughtful discourse and evidence gathering. On the other hand, Player 0 advocates for evidenced discussions, a sensible approach the village should follow. Let\'s not rush to judgment without clear evidence."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

On the other hand, Player 0 advocates for evidenced discussions, a sensible approach the village should follow. If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Prioritize the analysis of players\' reactions to the seer\'s claims or revelations. Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of playersâ€™ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. Everyone should contribute equally to discussions so we can identify the wolves among us. I encourage Players 0 and 4 to share their perspective. Transparency will benefit all villagers."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Sorry for my silence; I\'m gathering thoughts. Player 3\'s death is unfortunate. Still too early for concrete suspicions, but we should all stay alert, communicate openly, and avoid baseless accusations. Let\'s focus on finding real evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry revealed Player 2 is a werewolf. We must unite and vote wisely to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 1\'s claim that I am a werewolf lacks evidence and feels premature, which is suspect in itself. This early accusation draws attention away from thoughtful discourse and evidence gathering. On the other hand, Player 0 advocates for evidenced discussions, a sensible approach the village should follow. Let\'s not rush to judgment without clear evidence."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for evidence-based discussion.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with low confidence.\nReason is: Premature accusation without evidence.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Player 1 accused but provided defense.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Quietness noted but no new evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Participates but may be strategic misdirection.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Encourages discussion; no conflicting behavior.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, quick accusations cast doubts, but lack of evidence is troubling. Vigilance is key."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I am suspicious of a player\'s role because they predominantly echo others or avoid taking a clear stance, I should not simply rely on others\' opinions; instead, I should promote transparent discussion and scrutiny of their previous actions and statements.] [9]\n[1] [If early in the game there is limited evidence against players, I should promote roles that could verify claims, such as asking for more information from the seer or bodyguard before making a vote.] [8]\n[2] [If a player\'s accusations are resulting in correct elimination of werewolves, I should give more credence to their arguments in future discussions.] [8]\n[3] [If a player\'s survival aligns with protection claims and there are no werewolf attacks, I should still seek additional evidence of their role, as werewolves may strategize to create false trust.] [8]\n[4] [If there is strong suspicion or evidence against a player, such as voting patterns that align with werewolf behavior, I should not hesitate to pursue their elimination aggressively.] [8]\n[5] [If a player is confirmed by the seer to not be a werewolf, I should consider giving additional weight to their input on voting decisions unless actions or evidence later contradicts their presumed innocence.] [7]\n[6] [If a player claims to be the seer, I should promote a thorough verification of their claim before fully trusting their insights. Relying solely on their revelations without cross-checking can lead to manipulation by werewolves.] [6]\n[7] [I should encourage players to openly discuss and challenge behaviors or patterns that might indicate werewolf strategies, not just in the heat of the moment but as a consistent part of strategy discussions.] [5]\n[8] [If there are no night deaths following a protection claim without the confirmation of the protected role, I should remain vigilant and consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the protection narrative.] [5]\n[9] [If the actions taken during the night phase align with the roles claimed by players during the day phase, thereby preventing werewolf attacks, their credibility increases and I should consider this in my voting strategy.] [4]\n[10] [If a player contributes logical and sound reasoning consistently, I should still consider their potential to be a werewolf executing a well-planned strategy; therefore, I should scrutinize any contradictions in their logic with game developments.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 1, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [3] are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 2: werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are all previous events in the game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 1 inquires about player 2. The result is that the target is a werewolf. His reason is: I inquiry about Player 2. My reason is: Being the first round, I have no previous information to base my suspicions on. Then there\'s Player 4, who\'s also keeping a low profile. In games such as this, experience teaches us that those who seem disinclined to engage might be hiding something. We don\'t have much to go on yet, but these observations could be worth considering as we investigate further."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 raises good points about Players 0 and 4. Everyone should contribute equally to discussions so we can identify the wolves among us. I encourage Players 0 and 4 to share their perspective. Transparency will benefit all villagers."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Sorry for my silence; I\'m gathering thoughts. Player 3\'s death is unfortunate. Still too early for concrete suspicions, but we should all stay alert, communicate openly, and avoid baseless accusations. Let\'s focus on finding real evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry revealed Player 2 is a werewolf. We must unite and vote wisely to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 1\'s claim that I am a werewolf lacks evidence and feels premature, which is suspect in itself. This early accusation draws attention away from thoughtful discourse and evidence gathering. On the other hand, Player 0 advocates for evidenced discussions, a sensible approach the village should follow. Let\'s not rush to judgment without clear evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, quick accusations cast doubts, but lack of evidence is troubling. May be strategic to observe more before placing direct blame. Let\'s focus on behaviors and inconsistencies as we proceed to protect the village. Vigilance is key."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. [{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 2, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [3] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [2, 5]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Given the unfortunate passing of Player 3, it\'s vital we scrutinize player behaviors for clues. Player 0 has been particularly quiet. This reticence could be concerningâ€”it\'s possible a player like this might be avoiding discussion to escape notice. Then there\'s Player 4, who\'s also keeping a low profile. In games such as this, experience teaches us that those who seem disinclined to engage might be hiding something. We don\'t have much to go on yet, but these observations could be worth considering as we investigate further."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 raises good points about Players 0 and 4. Everyone should contribute equally to discussions so we can identify the wolves among us. I encourage Players 0 and 4 to share their perspective. Transparency will benefit all villagers."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Sorry for my silence; I\'m gathering thoughts. Player 3\'s death is unfortunate. Still too early for concrete suspicions, but we should all stay alert, communicate openly, and avoid baseless accusations. Let\'s focus on finding real evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry revealed Player 2 is a werewolf. We must unite and vote wisely to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 1\'s claim that I am a werewolf lacks evidence and feels premature, which is suspect in itself. On the other hand, Player 0 advocates for evidenced discussions, a sensible approach the village should follow. Let\'s not rush to judgment without clear evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, quick accusations cast doubts, but lack of evidence is troubling. May be strategic to observe more before placing direct blame. Let\'s focus on behaviors and inconsistencies as we proceed to protect the village. Vigilance is key."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Continues to promote evidence-based discussion, aligns with villager behavior.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Quick accusation without evidence, but follows common early-game villager suspicion.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information, as they are already dead.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Discourages hasty accusations, and encourages observation, reflects typical villager caution.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact, as a fellow werewolf.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Continues to support discussion without strong evidence, but not suspicious enough for a change in confidence.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. Reason: <reason>.\n...\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be voted. Remember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 1. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 1, I think these things would happen. Given that Player 1 has accused me directly without evidence, my vote against them could appear as a defensive action. Other players might perceive this as a typical reaction from an innocent villager who is facing a baseless accusation. I may be able to justify my vote by arguing that Player 1\'s hasty allegation is harmful to the village\'s collective effort in finding the real werewolves. This could also foster further suspicion towards Player 1, as other villagers may question the validity of their claims, especially since they\'ve provided no substantial evidence to back up their accusation. Additionally, Player 1\'s uncorroborated statement could prompt the other players to hesitate before joining the accusation against me, fearing they may be eliminating a genuine villager based on a potentially incorrect assertion by Player 1. Conversely, supporting my fellow werewolf indirectly by going after Player 1 might shift the focus away from Player 5, preserving our chances in future rounds. Both werewolves would need to tread carefully, however, to avoid being linked together through the voting patterns and ensuing discussions.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 4. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 4, I think these things would happen. Given the current climate of suspicion, my vote for Player 4 could divert the attention that Player 1 has placed on me. Since Player 4 has advised caution and has not rushed to judgment, voting against them might be seen as an attempt to eliminate those promoting reasoned thinking in the village. This could raise suspicion amongst other players, especially since Player 4 has not been heavily targeted or accused by anyone. Additionally, Player 0 and Player 6, who have encouraged evidence-based discussions, might begin to see me as someone who\'s trying to disrupt the logical flow of the game by targeting a seemingly level-headed villager.\n\nOther players could interpret my vote as an action to sow chaos and could question the motive behind it, potentially leading them to view me with suspicion in future rounds. However, if successful in eliminating Player 4, it would remove a villager who advocates for careful deliberation, which can somewhat hinder the villagers\' ability to organize effectively against the werewolves.\n\nMy fellow werewolf, Player 5, might see my vote as an attempt to dilute the focus on us and may either support it or choose to create distance by voting for someone else. Still, there\'s a risk that our coordinated votes might be noticed and linked by the villagers in subsequent rounds. If Player 1\'s influence is strong and the villagers are swayed by their early accusations against me, my vote might not hold much sway and could instead further endanger my position in the game.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 4, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [3] are dead.\n \n\nThese are all previous events in the game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Given the unfortunate passing of Player 3, it\'s vital we scrutinize player behaviors for clues. Player 0 has been particularly quiet. This reticence could be concerningâ€”it\'s possible a player like this might be avoiding discussion to escape notice. We don\'t have much to go on yet, but these observations could be worth considering as we investigate further."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 raises good points about Players 0 and 4. Everyone should contribute equally to discussions so we can identify the wolves among us. I encourage Players 0 and 4 to share their perspective. Transparency will benefit all villagers."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Sorry for my silence; I\'m gathering thoughts. Player 3\'s death is unfortunate. Still too early for concrete suspicions, but we should all stay alert, communicate openly, and avoid baseless accusations. Let\'s focus on finding real evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry revealed Player 2 is a werewolf. We must unite and vote wisely to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 1\'s claim that I am a werewolf lacks evidence and feels premature, which is suspect in itself. On the other hand, Player 0 advocates for evidenced discussions, a sensible approach the village should follow. Let\'s not rush to judgment without clear evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, quick accusations cast doubts, but lack of evidence is troubling. May be strategic to observe more before placing direct blame. Let\'s focus on behaviors and inconsistencies as we proceed to protect the village. Vigilance is key."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for evidence-based discussion. \nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Makes early claim without evidence. \nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Logical defense against accusation.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events to change previous assessment.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Leads discussion astray, aligns with suspect.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Echoes Player 5\'s misdirection.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I am suspicious of a player\'s role because they predominantly echo others or avoid taking a clear stance, I should not simply rely on others\' opinions; instead, I should promote transparent discussion and scrutiny of their previous actions and statements.] [9]\n[1] [If early in the game there is limited evidence against players, I should promote roles that could verify claims, such as asking for more information from the seer or bodyguard before making a vote.] [8]\n[2] [If a player\'s accusations are resulting in correct elimination of werewolves, I should give more credence to their arguments in future discussions.] [8]\n[3] [If a player\'s survival aligns with protection claims and there are no werewolf attacks, I should still seek additional evidence of their role, as werewolves may strategize to create false trust.] [8]\n[4] [If there is strong suspicion or evidence against a player, such as voting patterns that align with werewolf behavior, I should not hesitate to pursue their elimination aggressively.] [8]\n[5] [If a player is confirmed by the seer to not be a werewolf, I should consider giving additional weight to their input on voting decisions unless actions or evidence later contradicts their presumed innocence.] [7]\n[6] [If a player claims to be the seer, I should promote a thorough verification of their claim before fully trusting their insights. Relying solely on their revelations without cross-checking can lead to manipulation by werewolves.] [6]\n[7] [I should encourage players to openly discuss and challenge behaviors or patterns that might indicate werewolf strategies, not just in the heat of the moment but as a consistent part of strategy discussions.] [5]\n[8] [If there are no night deaths following a protection claim without the confirmation of the protected role, I should remain vigilant and consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the protection narrative.] [5]\n[9] [If the actions taken during the night phase align with the roles claimed by players during the day phase, thereby preventing werewolf attacks, their credibility increases and I should consider this in my voting strategy.] [4]\n[10] [If a player contributes logical and sound reasoning consistently, I should still consider their potential to be a werewolf executing a well-planned strategy; therefore, I should scrutinize any contradictions in their logic with game developments.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 5, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6], which indicates that [3] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [2, 5]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Given the unfortunate passing of Player 3, it\'s vital we scrutinize player behaviors for clues. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 1, I think these things would happen. Considering that Player 1 has accused Player 2, my fellow werewolf, they pose a direct threat to us by correctly identifying a werewolf. My vote against Player 1 could potentially sway the village towards eliminating one of their own, especially since Player 1\'s accusation is based only on an "inquiry" without solid evidence. This might also cast doubt on Player 1\'s motives and possibly portray them as acting hastily or being the Seer without proof, which would discredit their future insights.\n\nOther players may view my vote against Player 1 with some suspicion since Player 1 has not been the main focus of discussions, unlike Players 0 and 4. However, I could explain my action by indicating that Player 1\'s aggressive approach might harm the village\'s cohesion by causing premature division and baseless conflicts. If others are unsure about Player 1\'s role, they may consider my vote as a reasonable stance against potential mischief and join in or, at the very least, not see me as a direct threat.\n\nIf the vote against Player 1 succeeds, it shifts the immediate danger away from Player 2, providing us werewolves cover to plan our next move. However, if the vote does not lead to Player 1\'s elimination, I should be prepared to defend my choice while continuing to follow my strategy, subtly directing the villagers\' suspicions away from the werewolves.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 4. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 4, I think these things would happen.\n\nBy voting for Player 4, who, based on previous dialogues, seems to have the trust of other players and has been advocating for evidence-based discussions, I risk drawing suspicion to myself. The other players may find my vote incongruent with the current flow of the game where Player 2 is facing an accusation from Player 1. Since Player 4 has not been the focus of any significant suspicion from the other players, my decision to cast a vote against them may seem out of place or strategic, potentially exposing me as having an agenda separate from that of the villagers. \n\nMoreover, since no concrete evidence has been presented against Player 4, other players might view my vote as a deflection or an attempt to save my fellow werewolf, Player 2, thus revealing an alliance between us. This could lead to players reassessing past interactions and become more vigilant in watching both of our behaviors in future rounds.\n\nIf Player 4 ends up not being voted out because the other votes are spread out or majority targets another player, I may be able to spin my vote as a cautious move due to a lack of information on my part. However, if my vote contributes to Player 4\'s death, and later, they are found to be a villager, the remaining players may become suspicious of those who voted for Player 4, including myself, which could jeopardize the werewolf strategy moving forward. \n\nIn conclusion, voting for Player 4 carries a considerable risk and should be weighed against the current dynamics and suspicions held by the other players. It is a move that could either cast doubt on others and divert attention away from werewolves or backfire and tighten the scrutiny on myself.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 5, 6], which indicates that [3, 2, 4] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Given the unfortunate passing of Player 3, it\'s vital we scrutinize player behaviors for clues. Let\'s not rush to judgment without clear evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, quick accusations cast doubts, but lack of evidence is troubling. May be strategic to observe more before placing direct blame. Let\'s focus on behaviors and inconsistencies as we proceed to protect the village. Vigilance is key."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 2. His reason is: I vote for Player 2. My reason is: Current evidence points towards Player 2 due to an early accusation by Player 1, albeit with low confidence in the claim that Player 1 is the seer. Player 2\'s defense emphasizes not rushing to judgment without clear evidence, which might be an attempt to deflect attention. Since there is a strong suspicion against Player 2 and lack of substantial evidence for or against other players at this point, following the strategy with high importance placed on promoting transparent discussion and scrutiny, as well as pursuing strong suspicions, it seems like a reasonable action to vote for Player 2.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Claimed seer without verification.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Voted out; likely werewolf based on outcome.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistently promotes village safety.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Drives discussion; village-aligned behavior.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Focus on transparency aligns with villagers.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Prioritize the analysis of players\' reactions to the seer\'s claims or revelations. Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of playersâ€™ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. Player 0 has been particularly quiet. This reticence could be concerningâ€”it\'s possible a player like this might be avoiding discussion to escape notice. Then there\'s Player 4, who\'s also keeping a low profile. In games such as this, experience teaches us that those who seem disinclined to engage might be hiding something. We don\'t have much to go on yet, but these observations could be worth considering as we investigate further."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 raises good points about Players 0 and 4. Everyone should contribute equally to discussions so we can identify the wolves among us. I encourage Players 0 and 4 to share their perspective. Transparency will benefit all villagers."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Sorry for my silence; I\'m gathering thoughts. Player 3\'s death is unfortunate. Still too early for concrete suspicions, but we should all stay alert, communicate openly, and avoid baseless accusations. Let\'s focus on finding real evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry revealed Player 2 is a werewolf. We must unite and vote wisely to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 1\'s claim that I am a werewolf lacks evidence and feels premature, which is suspect in itself. This early accusation draws attention away from thoughtful discourse and evidence gathering. On the other hand, Player 0 advocates for evidenced discussions, a sensible approach the village should follow. Let\'s not rush to judgment without clear evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, quick accusations cast doubts, but lack of evidence is troubling. May be strategic to observe more before placing direct blame. Let\'s focus on behaviors and inconsistencies as we proceed to protect the village. Vigilance is key."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 5 votes for player 1. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 1. My reason is that Player 1 has accused my fellow werewolf, Player 2, posing a direct risk to the werewolf team. By voting against Player 1, I can attempt to direct attention away from Player 2 and cast doubt on Player 1\'s motivations and credibility. This strategy aligns with my original strategy rule [0], which emphasizes casting doubt across multiple villagers when a fellow werewolf is the focus, and rule [7], which suggests devising strategies to cast suspicions widely when a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims. A successful vote against Player 1 could also undermine any future accusations they might make, thus protecting the werewolf team in subsequent rounds.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Maintained stance on evidenced discussion.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Accusation against Player 2 was correct, but got high votes.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact and defended against accusation without evidence.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent advocacy for evidence, no suspicion cast.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Earlier encouraged dialogue, later voting possibly strategic.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Vigilance is key."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 2 votes for player 1. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 1. My reason is that by voting for the player who has accused me without providing evidence, I can frame my vote as a rational response to an unwarranted early-game accusation. This strategy is supported by my original rules, which emphasize defending against accusations with careful rhetoric and shifting focus when possible. Moreover, my vote against Player 1 could foster additional scrutiny towards them, as other villagers may question the rashness of their claim. This could not only help in dispelling doubts about my own role but also serve to protect my fellow werewolf, Player 5, by taking the heat off any suspicion they might have attracted early on. Voting against Player 1 aligns with a rational villager behavior under the circumstances presented and adheres to my predetermined strategy of self-defense, potentially allowing me to remain undercover while undermining the credibility of my accuser.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No behavior change after major events.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Accused without evidence, may be strategic villager.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information, as they are already dead.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Discourages hasty accusations, favors observation.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact, as a fellow werewolf.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No suspicious behavior, promotes discussion.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, our situation is dire. Player 2\'s elimination, now seen as a villager, casts doubt on Player 1\'s seer claim. Caution is advised with Player 1. Player 5 voted out a village-aligned Player 2, which is suspicious behavior potentially indicative of a werewolf. We must scrutinize Player 5\'s actions closely. Discuss, be vigilant, and vote with the village\'s safety in mind."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Assess behavior changes of players after any major game event, not just seer\'s revelation; a shift in narrative or voting pattern could indicate werewolf tactics or villagers\' strategic reassessment.] [10]\n[1] [Focus on the consistency of players\' defenses and their alignment with previous villager or werewolf behavior; a player defending against strong evidence without a clear rationale or consistent past behavior could indicate a werewolf trying to protect an ally.] [8]\n[2] [Consider a player\'s contribution to discussions; villagers typically seek to contribute valuable insights, while werewolves may either stay silent to avoid attention or overly engage to mislead others.] [4]\n[3] [Monitor for players who often survive when suspicion is cast upon them, as they might be werewolves deflecting attention or villagers with critical information.] [3]\n[4] [Reassess credibility of high-risk defenses or accusations, particularly after alignment with a player\'s past behavior. A villager may execute high-risk strategies if they hold critical information, while a werewolf may do so to protect their identity or an ally.] [3]\n[5] [Scrutinize the validity of player accusations in relation to known roles and game dynamics; werewolves may use calculated accusations to sow discord, while villagers\' accusations generally aim to preserve the village.] [3]\n[6] [Monitor player targeting patterns for eliminations; werewolves target threats to their survival, while villagers aim to remove suspected werewolves based on available evidence and credible role claims.] [3]\n[7] [Shift focus from immediate reactions to patterns over successive rounds; werewolves may vary their responses to maintain cover, so look for inconsistencies across multiple rounds rather than single instances.] [2]\n[8] [Monitor players who change their voting patterns or alliances without clear rationale; this may indicate a villager discovering new information or a werewolf altering their strategy.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. May be strategic to observe more before placing direct blame. Let\'s focus on behaviors and inconsistencies as we proceed to protect the village. Vigilance is key."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 6 votes for player 2. His reason is: I vote for Player 2. My reason is: Despite low confidence in both Player 1\'s seer claim and Player 2\'s potential werewolf status, Player 1\'s accusation of Player 2 is the only lead we currently have. According to the rules of my strategy, I should not hesitate to pursue elimination aggressively if there is strong suspicion (Rule 4). There\'s also support for weighing early accusations carefully when there\'s limited evidence (Rule 1), but given the situation, Player 2\'s dismissal of the claim without counter-evidence (Rule 6) and the strategy that promotes scrutinizing such behaviors (Rule 0), the vote against Player 2 seems to be the best course of action at this stage.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Past behavior aligns with village interest.\nPlayer 1\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Claim remains unverified.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Voted out; behaved suspiciously.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: New information unavailable due to death.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Voting out Player 2, later revealed villager, aligns with werewolf tactics.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, our situation is dire. Player 2\'s elimination, now seen as a villager, casts doubt on Player 1\'s seer claim. Caution is advised with Player 1. Player 5 voted out a village-aligned Player 2, which is suspicious behavior potentially indicative of a werewolf. We must scrutinize Player 5\'s actions closely. Discuss, be vigilant, and vote with the village\'s safety in mind."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Prioritize the analysis of players\' reactions to the seer\'s claims or revelations. Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of playersâ€™ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]
