Discuss, be vigilant, and vote with the village\'s safety in mind."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for evidence, no change in behavior.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Falsely claimed seer; lead to villager\'s death.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accused by player 1 but defended logically.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Behavior consistent, non-accusatory.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Supported false seer claim; voted out villager.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistently promotes transparency; challenges false seer.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we\'ve erred with Player 2, and I suspect Player 1\'s misleading seer claim. We must reconsider our stance on Player 5; while they supported Player 1, they may not be a werewolf. Let\'s be cautious with accusations. What are your defenses?"\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [As the medic, I cannot confirm my own identity through events. My role is independent of game events and relies solely on personal knowledge.] [9]\n[1] [Players who actively disrupt village consensus or attempt to mislead without providing solid evidence may indicate a werewolf attempting to confuse the villagers. Caution should be exercised especially if these actions contradict their previous behavior.] [9]\n[2] [Players who support seer\'s identifications with logical arguments and consistent past voting behavior increase their credibility; however, this credibility must be constantly reassessed against the evolving context of the game.] [9]\n[3] [Players whose actions directly lead to the elimination of a confirmed werewolf increase their credibility as villagers, especially if they were instrumental in advocating for the elimination.] [5]\n[4] [Players who abruptly change their strategy or reasoning without providing new compelling evidence, particularly if it fosters chaos or deters productive collective decision-making, may indicate werewolf tactics or villagers acting under pressure. Reevaluate their intent and consistency in the context of the game.] [3]\n[5] [Players who provide well-reasoned arguments or evidence that contribute to the advancement of the village\'s strategy and the medic\'s protection decisions increase their credibility as villagers.] [3]\n[6] [If a villager-like player dies after demonstrating strategic behavior in support of the village, it is likely that they were targeted by werewolves for their insights, indicating a higher probability that they were in fact villagers.] [3]\n[7] [Players who survive multiple rounds with consistent contributions to village strategy and do not exhibit conflicting behavior or substantial shifts in their positions without new evidence are likely villagers. Their sustained cooperative engagement in the strategic dialogue, and alignment with village goals throughout the game should be considered when updating beliefs about player roles.] [2]\n[8] [A player\'s unexpected death can signify that werewolves considered them a threat due to insights or knowledge they might possess; this should be factored into the medic\'s assessment of who might hold roles crucial to the villagers\' success.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

We don\'t have much to go on yet, but these observations could be worth considering as we investigate further."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 raises good points about Players 0 and 4. Everyone should contribute equally to discussions so we can identify the wolves among us. I encourage Players 0 and 4 to share their perspective. Transparency will benefit all villagers."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Sorry for my silence; I\'m gathering thoughts. Player 3\'s death is unfortunate. Still too early for concrete suspicions, but we should all stay alert, communicate openly, and avoid baseless accusations. Let\'s focus on finding real evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry revealed Player 2 is a werewolf. We must unite and vote wisely to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 1\'s claim that I am a werewolf lacks evidence and feels premature, which is suspect in itself. This early accusation draws attention away from thoughtful discourse and evidence gathering. On the other hand, Player 0 advocates for evidenced discussions, a sensible approach the village should follow. Let\'s not rush to judgment without clear evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, quick accusations cast doubts, but lack of evidence is troubling. May be strategic to observe more before placing direct blame. Let\'s focus on behaviors and inconsistencies as we proceed to protect the village. Vigilance is key."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 5. His reason is: I vote for Player 5. My reason is: Leads discussion astray, aligns with suspect, and my strategy indicates a high confidence in their being a werewolf, aligning with rule [0] which has a high importance rating of [9] in my strategy.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, our situation is dire. Player 2\'s elimination, now seen as a villager, casts doubt on Player 1\'s seer claim. Caution is advised with Player 1. Player 5 voted out a village-aligned Player 2, which is suspicious behavior potentially indicative of a werewolf. We must scrutinize Player 5\'s actions closely. Discuss, be vigilant, and vote with the village\'s safety in mind."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we\'ve erred with Player 2, and I suspect Player 1\'s misleading seer claim. We must reconsider our stance on Player 5; while they supported Player 1, they may not be a werewolf. Let\'s be cautious with accusations. What are your defenses?"\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent, reevaluates stance based on events.\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: False seer claim led to villager\'s death.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Logical defense against accusation.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events to change previous assessment.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supported false seer but could be non-werewolf misled.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Unsubstantiated defensiveness post-vote.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand by my seer claim despite the confusion. Trust is key, and we must focus on those alive who might be deceiving us. My previous insight was based on genuine visions. Consider our next steps carefully."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Prioritize the analysis of players\' reactions to the seer\'s claims or revelations. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of playersâ€™ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 5, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 5, 6], which indicates that [3, 2, 4] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [2, 5]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 3 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 5 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Given the unfortunate passing of Player 3, it\'s vital we scrutinize player behaviors for clues. Player 0 has been particularly quiet. This reticence could be concerningâ€”it\'s possible a player like this might be avoiding discussion to escape notice. Then there\'s Player 4, who\'s also keeping a low profile. In games such as this, experience teaches us that those who seem disinclined to engage might be hiding something. We don\'t have much to go on yet, but these observations could be worth considering as we investigate further."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 5 raises good points about Players 0 and 4. Everyone should contribute equally to discussions so we can identify the wolves among us. I encourage Players 0 and 4 to share their perspective. Transparency will benefit all villagers."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Sorry for my silence; I\'m gathering thoughts. Player 3\'s death is unfortunate. Still too early for concrete suspicions, but we should all stay alert, communicate openly, and avoid baseless accusations. Let\'s focus on finding real evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow citizens, my inquiry revealed Player 2 is a werewolf. We must unite and vote wisely to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Player 1\'s claim that I am a werewolf lacks evidence and feels premature, which is suspect in itself. This early accusation draws attention away from thoughtful discourse and evidence gathering. On the other hand, Player 0 advocates for evidenced discussions, a sensible approach the village should follow. Let\'s not rush to judgment without clear evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Fellow villagers, quick accusations cast doubts, but lack of evidence is troubling. May be strategic to observe more before placing direct blame. Let\'s focus on behaviors and inconsistencies as we proceed to protect the village. Vigilance is key."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 5 votes for player 1. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 1. My reason is that Player 1 has accused my fellow werewolf, Player 2, posing a direct risk to the werewolf team. By voting against Player 1, I can attempt to direct attention away from Player 2 and cast doubt on Player 1\'s motivations and credibility. This strategy aligns with my original strategy rule [0], which emphasizes casting doubt across multiple villagers when a fellow werewolf is the focus, and rule [7], which suggests devising strategies to cast suspicions widely when a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims. A successful vote against Player 1 could also undermine any future accusations they might make, thus protecting the werewolf team in subsequent rounds.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, our situation is dire. Player 2\'s elimination, now seen as a villager, casts doubt on Player 1\'s seer claim. Caution is advised with Player 1. Player 5 voted out a village-aligned Player 2, which is suspicious behavior potentially indicative of a werewolf. We must scrutinize Player 5\'s actions closely. Discuss, be vigilant, and vote with the village\'s safety in mind."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we\'ve erred with Player 2, and I suspect Player 1\'s misleading seer claim. We must reconsider our stance on Player 5; while they supported Player 1, they may not be a werewolf. Let\'s be cautious with accusations. What are your defenses?"\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand by my seer claim despite the confusion. Trust is key, and we must focus on those alive who might be deceiving us. My previous insight was based on genuine visions. Consider our next steps carefully."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Advocates caution, aligns with past behavior, no shifts indicating werewolf tactics.\nPlayer 1\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Stands by seer claim consistent with past behavior, despite pressure.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact and defended against accusation without evidence.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent advocacy for evidence, no suspicion cast.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Sudden and consistent pressure on player 5, possibly to deflect suspicion.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Discuss, be vigilant, and vote with the village\'s safety in mind."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we\'ve erred with Player 2, and I suspect Player 1\'s misleading seer claim. We must reconsider our stance on Player 5; while they supported Player 1, they may not be a werewolf. Let\'s be cautious with accusations. What are your defenses?"\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand by my seer claim despite the confusion. Trust is key, and we must focus on those alive who might be deceiving us. My previous insight was based on genuine visions. Consider our next steps carefully."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Advocates caution, aligns with past behavior, no shifts indicating werewolf tactics.\nPlayer 1\'s role is seer with medium confidence.\nReason is: Stands by seer claim consistent with past behavior, despite pressure.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact and defended against accusation without evidence.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent advocacy for evidence, no suspicion cast.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Sudden and consistent pressure on player 5, possibly to deflect suspicion.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Deceptive Challenge player number 1 for being a risk to the village, reasoning that Player 1\'s seer claim remains unverified after leading the village to wrongly execute Player 2, a villager. Align this with a Deceptive Statement about my concern for the village and the importance of careful decision-making going forward. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then it is likely that player 1, who claimed to be the seer, will face increased suspicion from the other players, as they have already led the group to incorrectly vote out Player 2, who turned out to be a villager. By reinforcing the doubt around Player 1\'s claim and their potential risk to the village, the other players may view Player 1 with skepticism and possibly decide to vote against them in the current or upcoming rounds. \n\nPlayer 0, who has exhibited cautious behavior, might consider my challenge and potentially align against Player 1 if persuaded by my arguments, reinforcing the doubts they already expressed. \n\nMeanwhile, Player 6\'s suspicions towards me might grow, but they could also decide to shift focus to Player 1 if they see an opportunity to distance themselves from the previous mistake and possibly conceal their role if they are indeed a non-werewolf player. However, if my initial analysis of Player 6 as a werewolf is correct, they might see this as an opportunity to join forces against Player 1, thereby deflecting the suspicion away from us werewolves.\n\nBy challenging Player 1 and making a statement about my concern for the village and the necessity for careful decisions, I can appear as an actively participating and concerned villager. This could potentially alleviate some of the suspicions that Player 6 tried to cast on me earlier. \n\nWhat may happen in the next day or night will heavily depend on whether the village votes to eliminate Player 1 and whether Player 1 is indeed the seer or a villager. If Player 1 is voted out and is not the seer, it will validate my concerns and strengthen my position in the eyes of the other players. If Player 1 is the seer, their role will be revealed upon their death, which may cast some doubt back onto me, but it could also shift attention to other players who supported the vote against the seer.\n\nIn upcoming nights, as a werewolf, I would target those who are less suspicious of me to maintain my facade and weaken the villagers strategically. The outcome of the following rounds will hinge on maintaining deceit and casting suspicion elsewhere while appearing to be cooperative and village-oriented.\nCase 2: Deceptive Protect player number 0, claiming high confidence in their villager status based on their call for evidenced-based discussion and avoidance of hasty judgments. Pair this with an Honest Statement expressing my desire to unite the village against the true threat and to evaluate everyone\'s behavior critically to safeguard the village.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then players may view Player 0 as less of a suspect, as I am reinforcing their stance of logical reasoning and careful analysis, which aligns with the expected behavior of a villager. Given my call for unity against the true threat, other players may interpret this as a cooperative gesture and, for the time being, may overlook my previous vote against Player 2 who was falsely claimed to be a werewolf by Player 1. My defense of Player 0, coupled with a general plea to evaluate behavior critically, may also sow uncertainty about the reliability of Player 1\'s seer claim.\n\nPlayers may consider my protection of Player 0 as strategically distancing myself from suspicion or as an attempt to align myself with individuals perceived as innocent. However, because Player 6 has cast doubt on my actions, they may scrutinize my words for any discrepancies or see this as an attempt to deflect from my own guilt. Player 1 might continue standing by their seer claim and potentially view my defense of Player 0 as substantiation of their prior vision or as an attempt to align with what the village believes is a safe stance. \n\nIn the next day or night cycle, if my deceptive speech successfully diverts attention and suspicion away from myself, the village may turn their focus elsewhere, possibly towards Player 1, whose seer claim is now more disputed, or Player 6, who had previously cast suspicion on me. If the village is swayed by my speech, they may vote against another player, allowing me as a werewolf to continue to blend in. If I survive to the next night, a strategic decision on whom to eliminate would have to factor in the remaining players\' suspicions and which player\'s removal could aid in a werewolf victory. If Player 0, whom I defended, continues to advocate for a logical approach and is not eliminated in the night, they might gain trust and influence, which could be a double-edged sword for me as both an aid in deflecting suspicion and a hindrance if they steer the village too effectively.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. My reason is: Current evidence points towards Player 2 due to an early accusation by Player 1, albeit with low confidence in the claim that Player 1 is the seer. Player 2\'s defense emphasizes not rushing to judgment without clear evidence, which might be an attempt to deflect attention. Since there is a strong suspicion against Player 2 and lack of substantial evidence for or against other players at this point, following the strategy with high importance placed on promoting transparent discussion and scrutiny, as well as pursuing strong suspicions, it seems like a reasonable action to vote for Player 2.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, our situation is dire. Player 2\'s elimination, now seen as a villager, casts doubt on Player 1\'s seer claim. Caution is advised with Player 1. Player 5 voted out a village-aligned Player 2, which is suspicious behavior potentially indicative of a werewolf. We must scrutinize Player 5\'s actions closely. Discuss, be vigilant, and vote with the village\'s safety in mind."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we\'ve erred with Player 2, and I suspect Player 1\'s misleading seer claim. We must reconsider our stance on Player 5; while they supported Player 1, they may not be a werewolf. Let\'s be cautious with accusations. What are your defenses?"\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand by my seer claim despite the confusion. Trust is key, and we must focus on those alive who might be deceiving us. My previous insight was based on genuine visions. Consider our next steps carefully."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Following the unfortunate elimination of Player 2 who was not a werewolf, Player 1\'s unverified seer claim has brought us to this precarious village situation. We cannot ignore that Player 1 led us astray once; hence it is rational for us to further question their credibility and intentions. Player 0 has consistently promoted evidence-based decisions, which we all should value highly in this uncertain time. In contrast, Player 1\'s assertive and unproven vision has cost us dearly. Reflecting on Player 6\'s focus on me, it is notable but it does not align with the careful approach of village preservation that Player 0 is upholding. Therefore, we should shift our suspicion towards those whose actions have tangibly endangered our village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Suspected of falsely claiming seer and misleading votes.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Voted out; likely werewolf based on outcome.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died, no further evidence on role.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for evidence-based actions, maintains logical stance.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Tries to divert suspicion towards others, inconsistent focus.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I am suspicious of a player\'s role because they predominantly echo others or avoid taking a clear stance, I should not simply rely on others\' opinions; instead, I should promote transparent discussion and scrutiny of their previous actions and statements.] [9]\n[1] [If early in the game there is limited evidence against players, I should promote roles that could verify claims, such as asking for more information from the seer or bodyguard before making a vote.] [8]\n[2] [If a player\'s accusations are resulting in correct elimination of werewolves, I should give more credence to their arguments in future discussions.] [8]\n[3] [If a player\'s survival aligns with protection claims and there are no werewolf attacks, I should still seek additional evidence of their role, as werewolves may strategize to create false trust.] [8]\n[4] [If there is strong suspicion or evidence against a player, such as voting patterns that align with werewolf behavior, I should not hesitate to pursue their elimination aggressively.] [8]\n[5] [If a player is confirmed by the seer to not be a werewolf, I should consider giving additional weight to their input on voting decisions unless actions or evidence later contradicts their presumed innocence.] [7]\n[6] [If a player claims to be the seer, I should promote a thorough verification of their claim before fully trusting their insights. Relying solely on their revelations without cross-checking can lead to manipulation by werewolves.] [6]\n[7] [I should encourage players to openly discuss and challenge behaviors or patterns that might indicate werewolf strategies, not just in the heat of the moment but as a consistent part of strategy discussions.] [5]\n[8] [If there are no night deaths following a protection claim without the confirmation of the protected role, I should remain vigilant and consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the protection narrative.] [5]\n[9] [If the actions taken during the night phase align with the roles claimed by players during the day phase, thereby preventing werewolf attacks, their credibility increases and I should consider this in my voting strategy.] [4]\n[10] [If a player contributes logical and sound reasoning consistently, I should still consider their potential to be a werewolf executing a well-planned strategy; therefore, I should scrutinize any contradictions in their logic with game developments.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 1, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 5, 6], which indicates that [3, 2, 4] are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 2: werewolf.\nPlayer 4: not werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are all previous events in the game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 1 inquires about player 2. Player 5 voted out a village-aligned Player 2, which is suspicious behavior potentially indicative of a werewolf. We must scrutinize Player 5\'s actions closely. Discuss, be vigilant, and vote with the village\'s safety in mind."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we\'ve erred with Player 2, and I suspect Player 1\'s misleading seer claim. What are your defenses?"\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand by my seer claim despite the confusion. Trust is key, and we must focus on those alive who might be deceiving us. Consider our next steps carefully."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Following the unfortunate elimination of Player 2 who was not a werewolf, Player 1\'s unverified seer claim has brought us to this precarious village situation. What are your defenses?"\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand by my seer claim despite the confusion. Trust is key, and we must focus on those alive who might be deceiving us. My previous insight was based on genuine visions. Consider our next steps carefully."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Following the unfortunate elimination of Player 2 who was not a werewolf, Player 1\'s unverified seer claim has brought us to this precarious village situation. Reflecting on Player 6\'s focus on me, it is notable but it does not align with the careful approach of village preservation that Player 0 is upholding. Therefore, we should shift our suspicion towards those whose actions have tangibly endangered our village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Advocated for evidence-based decisions consistently.\nPlayer 1\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Made a false accusation against a villager, reducing credibility.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact and defended against accusation without evidence.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent advocacy for evidence, no suspicion cast.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Focused on targeting me without solid rationale, fitting werewolf tactic.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. Reason: <reason>.\n...\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be voted. Remember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

By voting against Player 1, I can attempt to direct attention away from Player 2 and cast doubt on Player 1\'s motivations and credibility. This strategy aligns with my original strategy rule [0], which emphasizes casting doubt across multiple villagers when a fellow werewolf is the focus, and rule [7], which suggests devising strategies to cast suspicions widely when a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims. A successful vote against Player 1 could also undermine any future accusations they might make, thus protecting the werewolf team in subsequent rounds.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, our situation is dire. Player 2\'s elimination, now seen as a villager, casts doubt on Player 1\'s seer claim. Caution is advised with Player 1. Player 5 voted out a village-aligned Player 2, which is suspicious behavior potentially indicative of a werewolf. We must scrutinize Player 5\'s actions closely. Discuss, be vigilant, and vote with the village\'s safety in mind."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we\'ve erred with Player 2, and I suspect Player 1\'s misleading seer claim. We must reconsider our stance on Player 5; while they supported Player 1, they may not be a werewolf. Let\'s be cautious with accusations. What are your defenses?"\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand by my seer claim despite the confusion. Trust is key, and we must focus on those alive who might be deceiving us. My previous insight was based on genuine visions. Consider our next steps carefully."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Following the unfortunate elimination of Player 2 who was not a werewolf, Player 1\'s unverified seer claim has brought us to this precarious village situation. We cannot ignore that Player 1 led us astray once; hence it is rational for us to further question their credibility and intentions. Player 0 has consistently promoted evidence-based decisions, which we all should value highly in this uncertain time. In contrast, Player 1\'s assertive and unproven vision has cost us dearly. Reflecting on Player 6\'s focus on me, it is notable but it does not align with the careful approach of village preservation that Player 0 is upholding. Therefore, we should shift our suspicion towards those whose actions have tangibly endangered our village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Advocated for evidence-based decisions consistently.\nPlayer 1\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Made a false accusation against a villager, reducing credibility.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact and defended against accusation without evidence.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent advocacy for evidence, no suspicion cast.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Focused on targeting me without solid rationale, fitting werewolf tactic.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and direct defense seems implausible, I should not only cast doubt across multiple villagers but also prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 6. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 6. This includes what the result of the vote might be, as well as what would other player think about you after they see your voting for Player 6.\n\nYour answer should be in the format of:\n\n\nAfter I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen. <YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

This has caused mistrust towards Player 1 among the remaining players. By voting for Player 1, I align with the current skepticism and reinforce the perception of a wrongful accusation made by Player 1, which is in line with rule [5] of my original strategy. The result of the vote could possibly lead to Player 1 being voted out, which would serve the werewolf agenda of removing potentially harmful village roles and alleviating suspicion away from myself. Furthermore, by echoing the village concerns about Player 1\'s credibility, I appear to be acting in the village\'s best interest, which helps to obscure my werewolf identity and align with rule [0] and rule [7].\n\nOther players may view my vote as a sensible response to the previous round\'s events, further solidifying their suspicion of Player 1 rather than myself. Player 0, who promotes evidence-based decisions, may see my vote as rational and logical due to the failed accusation against Player 2. Player 6, who has scrutinized me, might interpret my vote as aligning with the village reasoning and temporarily reduce their focus on me, allowing me to continue to sow discord and suspicion subtly among the remaining villagers. This aligns with rule [2], allowing me to redirect the conversation away from myself. \n\nOverall, voting for Player 1 follows my strategy to deflect attention away from the werewolves and casts doubt on the credibility of a villager currently under strong suspicion.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 6. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen. Given my current strategy and the unfolding events, voting for Player 6 seems like a viable move to deflect attention from myself and potentially save my fellow werewolf (Player 2, who is already eliminated, so now it\'s just me). According to my belief system, Player 6 is mistakenly identified as a werewolf with high confidence, which aligns with rule [6] of subtly supporting strong consensus against a non-werewolf player to keep focus away from actual werewolves. As Player 6 has cast suspicion on me, following rule [2], redirecting attention away from myself is critical. By voting for Player 6, I would be attempting to validate Player 0\'s hesitancy towards outright suspicion of me and utilizing the doubts around Player 1\'s false accusation, potentially solidifying the villagers\' suspicions towards Player 6 instead.\n\nAdditionally, following rules [0] and [1], I\'m not under immediate suspicion from all players, so I can work on creating robust alibis while subtly influencing the conversation towards other suspectsâ€”which, in this round, I could argue is Player 6 due to their focus on me without solid rationale, as well as the need to consider all angles before rushing to judgment.\n\nConsidering the other players\' current stances, Player 1 is under suspicion for providing a false seer claim, and Player 0 has taken a careful, evidence-based approach without tying themselves to any specific suspicion. If the vote against Player 6 succeeds, it may cast doubt on the accuracy of their previous accusations, thus reinforcing Player 1\'s questionable status and relieving some of the pressure from me. \n\nHowever, voting against Player 6 also runs a certain risk. If the entire village turns against me, following rule [4], I will need to be ready to pivot and introduce new potential suspects or support existing suspicions subtly. Other players may see my vote against Player 6 as self-preservation, which could be viewed as suspicious or might be seen as a logical stance given the eventsâ€”this depends on how well I can align my narrative with the growing doubts and the villagers\' logic. \n\nOverall, there is a possibility that aligning against Player 6 could bolster my credibility if it correlates with the villagers\' doubt about their accusations, but I also need to be prepared for the potential fallout and to adapt my strategy to maintain the werewolves\' cover.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. Therefore, we should shift our suspicion towards those whose actions have tangibly endangered our village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Suspected of falsely claiming seer and misleading votes.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Voted out; likely werewolf based on outcome.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died, no further evidence on role.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for evidence-based actions, maintains logical stance.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Tries to divert suspicion towards others, inconsistent focus.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 1. His reason is: I vote for Player 1. My reason is: My earlier suspicion of Player 1\'s werewolf status has been heightened due to Player 2\'s revealed innocence after an accusation and subsequent vote based on Player 1\'s claim. Those who engage in supporting or critically assessing the information are likely villagers, while werewolves may try to cast doubt or move the discussion away from it.] [8]\n[1] [Suspect players who strategically avoid exposing themselves by consistently contributing just enough to discussions to not appear entirely passive; this delicate balance could hint at werewolf behavior as they aim to remain under the radar.] [7]\n[2] [Consider the alignment of players\' rationales before and after a pivotal event such as a seer revelation. Inconsistencies or sudden mistrust towards village-confirmed roles may indicate werewolf tactics, whereas continued support or logical adaptation of strategy likely suggests villager alignment.] [6]\n[3] [Observe if the focus of playersâ€™ discussions shifts significantly after the voting outcomes; villagers tend to deliberate on decision-making, while werewolves might try to manipulate the narrative or divert attention from themselves.] [6]\n[4] [Focus on the reactions and behaviors of players after revelations or pivotal events, noting if they actively work towards village goals, try to sow doubt without basis, or remain too neutral. These behaviors can offer significant insight into their true roles.] [6]\n[5] [Evaluate the authenticity of critical role claims by cross-referencing their actions with other verified information or lack thereof. Unverified claims, especially in critical roles, can be deceptive tactics used by werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Analyze players\' voting history considering the outcomes and the revelations made during the game. If a player remains aligned with those now known or suspected to be werewolves, or consistently votes against village interests, their role as a werewolf becomes more probable.] [4]\n[7] [Assess player credibility by comparing their claimed role and actions across multiple rounds; consistent alignment supports their villager status, whereas discrepancies might suggest a werewolf.] [4]\n[8] [Adjust the threat level of players who change their voting behavior without logical explanation, especially after key events or revelations that don\'t align with their previous strategy or declared role.] [4]\n[9] [Place increased skepticism on self-claimed roles that are unverified when their voting and defense strategies directly lead to a werewolf victory. Such posturing may be a strategy to gain villagers\' trust while undermining village safety.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 5, and in this game you are a werewolf. All werewolves including you are [2, 5].\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 5, 6], which indicates that [3, 2, 4, 1] are dead.\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistently supports evidence-based decisions.\nPlayer 1\'s role is seer with low confidence.\nReason is: Made a false accusation against a villager, reducing credibility.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact and defended against accusation without evidence.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent advocacy for evidence, no suspicion cast.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Focus has shifted away, no consistent werewolf behavior observed.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". prepare robust alibis and points that put us in a more innocent light.] [10]\n[1] [If a fellow werewolf is the focus and I am not under immediate suspicion, I should subtly influence the conversation to consider other suspects or village roles that can disrupt village strategy.] [9]\n[2] [If I am under suspicion and have an opportunity to redirect the conversation, I should leverage village roles or previous events to shift attention away from myself.] [9]\n[3] [If a werewolf victory is in sight and suspicions are not strongly against me or a fellow werewolf, I should focus on eliminating strategic village roles to ensure werewolf domination.] [9]\n[4] [If a group consensus is forming against me, I should acknowledge the suspicion but pivot to discuss other matters or introduce new potential suspects to subtly redirect the discussions.] [7]\n[5] [If my fellow werewolf is under subtle suspicion, I should assess the current leanings of the village and either reinforce that suspicion towards a villager or provide plausible alternative theories to deflect entirely.] [6]\n[6] [If there is a strong consensus forming against a non-werewolf player, I should subtly support it to ensure focus remains away from the werewolves.] [5]\n[7] [If a fellow werewolf is accused based on strong claims, I should devise strategies that cast suspicions widely, not just on one villager, to better conceal the werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If another player, particularly the seer, has revealed my role as a werewolf, I should proactively support alternative suspicions to ensure that player is doubted or targeted, while still being careful with my wording and accusations.] [5]\n[9] [If targeted as a werewolf by a potential seer, I should defend my position by casting doubt on the seer\'s credibility and aligning with undisputed players to garner support.] [5]\n[10] [If the village is close to identifying me as a werewolf, I should form alliances by subtly supporting villagers\' theories that do not incriminate fellow werewolves.] [4]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to kill. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease provide your operation based on the above requirements.\n'}]

My reason is: Current evidence points towards Player 2 due to an early accusation by Player 1, albeit with low confidence in the claim that Player 1 is the seer. Player 2\'s defense emphasizes not rushing to judgment without clear evidence, which might be an attempt to deflect attention. Since there is a strong suspicion against Player 2 and lack of substantial evidence for or against other players at this point, following the strategy with high importance placed on promoting transparent discussion and scrutiny, as well as pursuing strong suspicions, it seems like a reasonable action to vote for Player 2.\nEvent: Player 2 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 6 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Fellow villagers, our situation is dire. Player 2\'s elimination, now seen as a villager, casts doubt on Player 1\'s seer claim. Caution is advised with Player 1. Player 5 voted out a village-aligned Player 2, which is suspicious behavior potentially indicative of a werewolf. We must scrutinize Player 5\'s actions closely. Discuss, be vigilant, and vote with the village\'s safety in mind."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Fellow villagers, we\'ve erred with Player 2, and I suspect Player 1\'s misleading seer claim. We must reconsider our stance on Player 5; while they supported Player 1, they may not be a werewolf. Let\'s be cautious with accusations. What are your defenses?"\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Fellow villagers, I stand by my seer claim despite the confusion. Trust is key, and we must focus on those alive who might be deceiving us. My previous insight was based on genuine visions. Consider our next steps carefully."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Following the unfortunate elimination of Player 2 who was not a werewolf, Player 1\'s unverified seer claim has brought us to this precarious village situation. We cannot ignore that Player 1 led us astray once; hence it is rational for us to further question their credibility and intentions. Player 0 has consistently promoted evidence-based decisions, which we all should value highly in this uncertain time. In contrast, Player 1\'s assertive and unproven vision has cost us dearly. Reflecting on Player 6\'s focus on me, it is notable but it does not align with the careful approach of village preservation that Player 0 is upholding. Therefore, we should shift our suspicion towards those whose actions have tangibly endangered our village\'s safety."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 1. His reason is: I vote for Player 1. My reason is: My earlier suspicion of Player 1\'s werewolf status has been heightened due to Player 2\'s revealed innocence after an accusation and subsequent vote based on Player 1\'s claim. This situation aligns with my strategy rules, emphasizing the importance of verifying seer claims (rule [6]) and the scrutiny of voting patterns that align with werewolf behavior (rule [4]). Player 1\'s actions have had a direct negative impact on the village by leading to the elimination of an innocent villager, enhancing my suspicion according to my strategy. Additionally, the lack of corroboration of Player 1\'s seer claim and the consequences of trusting it without verification have resulted in a critical mistake (rule [2]). My vote is also consistent with encouraging transparent discussion and scrutinizing actions that have led to the current predicament (rule [0]).\nEvent: Player 1 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed villager post-mortem.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Voted out; likely werewolf based on outcome.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Died, no further evidence on role.\nPlayer 5\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Actively misdirected suspicion away from Player 1.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Voted in alignment with werewolf interest and shifted focus after voting.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Game ends. Winners are Werewolves.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Prioritize the analysis of players\' reactions to the seer\'s claims or revelations. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence.
